;"Is there destined to be a war between China and the United States? My answer Yes, no." Joseph Nye, a professor at Harvard Kennedy School, gave a negative answer.

;

;Joseph Nye is a representative figure of the neoliberal school of international relations. Before and after the Cold War, Joseph Nye was famous for proposing the concept of "soft power". Soft power refers to a country's strength other than economic and military strength, and mainly refers to influence such as culture, values, and public opinion.

;

;He served successively as Assistant Secretary of State in the Carter administration, Chairman of the National Intelligence Council and Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Clinton administration. He is also a leading figure in American politics. But he reminded that the history of mankind is full of situations where wars "accidentally" entered. As long as China and the United States strengthen cooperation and act cautiously, wars can be avoided.

;

;China-US relations are one of the most important bilateral relations in the world today. On October 27, 2023, U.S. President Biden met at the White House with visiting member of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee and Foreign Minister Wang Yi.

;

;Since October 23, Joseph Nye has embarked on his first visit to China after the COVID-19 epidemic. Judging from the public schedule in just one week, the "Father of Soft Power" has successively attended speeches at many think tanks and universities.

;

;On the afternoon of October 25, in the Qiulin Lecture Hall of the School of International Relations at Peking University, Joseph Nye spoke with the topic "Are China and the United States destined to have a war?" Hundreds of teachers and students discussed "The History and Future of Sino-US Relations." The conference was jointly hosted by the School of International Relations at Peking University and the Institute of International Strategic Studies at Peking University.

;

;Joseph Nye once proposed the "20-year cycle theory of Sino-US relations", that is, since the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States, the ups and downs of the relationship between the two countries have been based on a 20-year cycle. And change.

;

;"In the long run, China and the United States will have better relations. But in the short term, China and the United States still have differences to resolve." Joseph Nye told the South Weekend reporter.

;

;Joseph Nye believes that after 2017, Sino-US relations entered a cycle of great power competition. "China-U.S. relations have gotten worse in the past. In a sense, I think we have seen the deterioration of Sino-U.S. relations, but I hope things will get better." Joseph Nye told Southern Weekend reporters.

;

;In recent years, discussions about the "new cold war" between China and the United States have been rampant in European and American public opinion circles.

;

;In Joseph Nye's view, the Cold War between China and the United States is completely incommensurable with the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union. “During the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union, although there was military and political competition between the two countries, their economic and social ties were very sparse. But now China and the United States are highly interdependent in many fields such as economy, society, and ecology. ”

;

;In 2020, Joseph Nye wrote an article in the "Wall Street Journal" that the Cold War between China and the United States is completely avoidable.

;

;Joseph Nye supports China and the United States in strengthening cooperation in public health, climate change and other fields.

;

;"Exchanges between China and the United States should be open to everyone. Exchanges at the cultural and scientific levels are equally important." Joseph Nye told Southern Weekend reporters that he hopes The public's attention should not only focus on high-level people, but also exert soft power. Low-level contacts are also very important.

;

;;The following is an interview with Joseph Nye:;

;

; Sino-US relations have gotten worse in the past. In a sense, we have seen a deterioration in Sino-US relations, but I hope things will get better.

;

;Unfortunately, during the COVID-19 epidemic, communication between China and the United States has not been sufficient. However, communication between China and the United States has begun to change. The United States sent important cabinet members to visit China, and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi also arrived in Washington for a visit.

;

;I think Sino-US relations are making progress. Two years ago, Sino-US relations were worse than they are now. What we're seeing today is some pickup, and I hope it continues.

;

;Among China and the United States, China not only has strong economic performance, but also has the attraction of traditional culture. I believe that a country’s soft power comes not only from government actions but also from civil society.

;

;The U.S. government often does some unpopular things, but despite this, America's civil society remains attractive to others because it is relatively free. Therefore, the soft power of the United States comes more from universities, non-profit organizations, and foundations, such as the Bill Gates Foundation.

;

;It is undeniable that people's views of the United States have gone up and down in recent years. In my opinion, the soft power of the United States has gone up and down. During the Vietnam War and when U.S. troops invaded Iraq, U.S. soft power was declining. The soft power of the United States returned again with the election of Obama as President of the United States in 2008, and fell together with Trump (who became President of the United States) in 2016.

;

;Soft power does not decline linearly or rise linearly. It is often cyclical.

;

;Now, the soft power of the United States is weakening due to internal divisions within the United States. On the other hand, if you look at the hard power of the United States, you will see that the U.S. economy is booming. The United States is a wellspring of innovation, leading in technological fields such as biotechnology and artificial intelligence. Looking at the situation in the Middle East today, (U.S.) military power is still very important.

;

;The Biden administration has been in power for three years and has a more balanced view (compared to the Trump administration). They still believe there are still benefits to working with China.

;

;In May this year, the G7 summit changed its focus on decoupling from China to de-risking on China. This expression means Countries outside the G7 will adopt partial decoupling from China, mostly in the security field.

;

;In other words, de-risking does not mean completely cutting off economic ties, but there are limits. U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan called it "building a high wall around a small yard." We should not let this small yard grow.

;

;To prevent deterioration, Sino-US relations should start with high-level contacts. Next, look for areas of cooperation between China and the United States, which can convey to the public of both countries that cooperation with another country is beneficial.

;

;I think this is an area where China and the United States can strengthen cooperation (position on the Russia-Ukraine conflict).

;

;China and the United States can also strengthen cooperation in other areas, such as climate change and working with the WHO to respond to epidemics.

;

;Exchanges between China and the United States should be open to everyone. Obviously, people always focus on the president or the cabinet. Exchange on cultural and scientific levels is equally important. If we need to build trust and cooperation (with each other) and exert soft power, low-level engagement is very important.

;

;(Sino-US relations) have become increasingly complex and difficult to resolve in the short term. I tend to use "short-term pessimists" and "long-term optimists" to describe China and the United States as not posing a threat to each other. In the long run, China and the United States will have better relations. But in the short term, China and the United States still have differences to resolve.
